title: Busy Philipp's husband wasn't helping her with their kids, so she almost divorced him
text:
CLOSE

Busy Philipps shares what almost broke up her marriage to her husband. (Photo: Frazer Harrison, Getty Images)

Busy Philipps was fed up with handling all of the household and childcare duties herself, so she threatened to divorce her husband.

In an interview with Harper's Bazaar, Philipps revealed that she wanted to end her 12-year marriage to Marc Silverstein because he wasn't helping take care of their two daughters, Birdie and Cricket.

"My thinking was that if I leave, at least then maybe I’d get two days off a week,” Philipps told the outlet. “I understand that I’m in a place of privilege, and even if I left Marc and I’d been super down on my luck, there was a version of life that I could have made work for me and my daughters. This is not the reality for many women."

'He made the call'

Silverstein wasn't here for ending their marriage, so he stepped up. The "Dawson's Creek" alum said her husband was willing to do anything to save their marriage.

"And he made the call: He should be the one to stay home with the kids," the actress said. Silverstein began taking over childcare duties for their two girls. He became responsible for Birdie's morning and bedtime routine and cooking meals for the household.

"I was fully out the door,” Philipps told Harper's Bazaar. "I wasn’t expecting anything from him, but what we ended up doing was creating our own system."

The roles in Philipps' household changed up dramatically to the point that Silverstein's relationship with his daughters became stronger.

"He now loves his mornings with the girls,” Philipps said. "He’ll make my Bulletproof coffee and bring it into the bedroom while I’m still sleeping, and then leave to take the kids to school. He has conversations with them that I’m jealous of. The closeness he now has with these girls, it’s really special."

Silverstein opened up about why he was so absent in the household and it had to do with his confidence.

"I like being good at stuff," Silverstein told the outlet. "And I didn’t feel like I was good (in the home), so I stayed away."

Seven years of unpaid labor

Philipps joins Melinda Gates, wife of Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, in famous moms who say that equally splitting household chores and child care duties has helped their marriage.

Gates told Business Insider that their 25-year-long marriage works because she and Bill equally divide the unpaid work it takes to run a household.

She added that the "unpaid labor" that typically women do can be equivalent to seven years.

"One thing in society we have put on women is we don't talk about how difficult it is to raise children, how much time it takes. We don't even talk about things like breastfeeding. We just assume women are going to go do it. It takes time and it takes energy, right? ...When you add it up over their lifetime, it's seven years of work. I don't know about you, but I think you and I could probably go and get a couple of graduate degrees and a Ph.D. in seven years.

"Some of that's work you want to do. It's tender; it's lovely. But some of it is also the mundane of doing laundry and the dishes and packing lunch boxes."
